docs.lead_paragraph: So a week after college football (Big Boys Acting Badly) starts and in the middle of the United States Tennis Open (Brathood on Parade), here comes pro football (Fat Men Fighting). May we call this the Psycho Season? ''I wouldn't go that far,'' says the psychologist, speaking softly, picking his words carefully, ''but there is no question that the competitive aspects are tightening; we demand more from our superstars and give them more.'' He picks up speed, speaking without punctuation. ''The owners are stretched and need more money so they raise prices and the fans want to see a winner not someone kicked in the face and left on the ground for dead like they are every day of the week and I ask you where does it all start?''

headline.main: Seeking a Way to Win Athletes' Mind Games

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte profiles sports psychologist Jim Loehr; photo (M)
